data.name: Little Boy
data.description: Little Boy had its debut on August 6, 1945 when the U.S. dropped it over the city of Hiroshima, Japan. The blast resulted in 66,000 deaths and 69,000 injuries. While many others were produced during this time, Little Boy was the only one to actually be used in combat; similarly, it was the first nuclear bomb ever used in war.

data.name: Fat Man
data.description: Fat Man previewed days after Little Boy on August 9, 1945 when it was dropped on Nagasaki, Japan. While Fat Man was bigger than Little Boy, it didn't hit its' target dead center, leading to only 35,000-45,000 deaths compared to Little Boy's 66,000. Fat Man was the third man-made nuclear explosion ever set off, and more than 120 Fat Man bombs were created between 1947 and 1949. In 1950, Fat Man was retired.

data.name: RDS-1
data.description: RDS-1 was the Soviet Union's first nuclear weapon test. Development began in 1946, and took years to complete. This bomb was created similarly to the United States' Fat Man because USSR received extensive intelligence on it. Upon testing, the bomb actually proved 50% more destructive than engineers had expected. The RDS-1 was the start of a series of Russian nuclear bombs. RDS-1 was also known as First Lightning.

data.name: Hurricane
data.description: Project Hurricane was the first British testing of Nuclear bombs. Hurricane closely resembles the design of United States' Fat Man because several key British scientists who had worked on the Manhattan Project came back to Britain to help develop Hurricane. Unlike most other test scenarios, the British tested Hurricane in the hull of a ship ~1,000ft off the coast of Trimouille Island.

data.name: Ivy Mike
data.description: Ivy Mike was the first full scale thermo-nuclear device to be tested in which part of the explosive yield comes from nuclear fusion. Due to it's physical size and fuel type, Ivy Mike actually was not suitable as a weapon. The 82ton bomb was more of a factory than an actual bomb.

data.name: Castle Bravo
data.description: The most powerful bomb ever detonated by the United States, Castle Bravo was the first U.S. test of a dry fuel hydrogen bomb. This bomb was designed along the same pattern as Ivy Mike, but it was a priority to ensure this time that the bomb could actually be dropped from a plane. When this bomb was tested on March 1, 1954, the fireball from it was from over 250 miles away. At peak, the mushroom cloud reached a height of 130,000 ft and a diameter of 62 miles. After this explosion, there was much nuclear fallout that affected some islands and other nations, creating a lot of international reaction about atmospheric thermonuclear testing.

data.name: RDS-37
data.description: The RDS-37 was originally designed with a yield of 3000kT; however, it was scaled down before testing on November 22. This bomb was the Soviet Union's first two-stage hydrogen bomb. Despite the reduction, because of the bomb's drop location, it happened to cause a shock wave to roll across the ground and cause trench and building collapses up to 40 miles away, killing a few soldiers and a school girl.

data.name: Orange Herald
data.description: While this bomb was claimed to be a hydrogen bomb at first, it was actually just a large boosted fission bomb. This bomb was quickly manufactured by the British to show that they are capable of creating megaton level weapons before a ban on atmospheric testing was enacted. There were actually two versions of Orange Herald- a small and a large. For testing, the UK used the smaller one.

data.name: Tsar Bomba
data.description: The Tsar Bomba is the largest man made artificial explosion in human history. This bomb was tested in the Arctic Circle with no human civilization within 100 miles of the testing grounds. When dropped, the shockwave from this bomb actually caused the plane that dropped it to fall 1kM in air before stabilizing. The fireball from this bomb was as high as the altitude of the release plane, and was visible over 620 miles away. At peak, the mushroom cloud reached a height of 40 miles (7x that of Mt. Everest) and a width of 59 miles. The shockwave from this explosion was still felt 430 miles away, and windowpanes were partially broken at distances of 960 miles away. Even in Norway and Sweden, windows were shattered from the blast. This bomb would have caused third degree burns on any unprotected individual within 100 miles.
